instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message:
Very new to this so may be an obvious one.

Corrosion around the area pictured.

Fuses and resistors in this area test ok.

Have replaced:

<CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7035</CAPACITOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7931</TRANSISTOR>

Pulses the green charger light the same as it did before the swaps. Fans spins for between 0.5 - 3 seconds every 1-2 seconds. If you listen [B][I]very[/I][/B] carefully, a tick.. tick....tick noise is coming from somewhere over the side of the board where the corrosion was, at least that's where it appears to be coming from. When the fan is spinning the tick...tick.tick disappears. This was still audible when all of the above components were off the board. Any clues please.

Cheers

Stewart

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: Resistance between pins 17 and 18 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>? Also pins 27 and 28?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: Wow, thanks for the quick response. Will check in the morning. I'm beat, it's late here.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: Hi, just checked and no resistance at all from those points.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: So <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is shorted or both <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> are. My bet would be <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: Thanks for the reply. Unless the donor <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is also faulty, no joy with replacement. Back to the same situation. Ticking persisted even with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> off the board. <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> don't test as shorted...

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuates?
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> too?
Post voltages as <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>...

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.6v while pulsing/ticking 11.65v when fan spinning
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.45v Constant

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>:

Pin1 = 16.3v Constant - 0.1-0.2v drop when fan starts
Pin2 = 16.3v Constant - 0.1-0.2v drop when fan starts
Pin3 = 3.9v Constant - 0.1-0.2v drop when fan starts
Pin4 = 3.42v Fan off, 0v Fan Spinning
Pin5 = 0.2v Fan Off, 2.8v Fan Spinning
Pin6 = 3.45 Constant
Pin7 = 0.7v Fan Off, 2.8v Fan Spinning
Pin8 = 0.44 Fan Off 1.63v Fan Spinning
Pin9 = 0.03v Constant
Pin10 = 3.45v Constant - 0.1-0.2v drop when fan starts
Pin11 = 3.45v Constant - 0.1-0.2v drop when fan starts
Pin12 = 3.45v Constant
Pin13 = 3.14v Constant
Pin14 = 2.36v Constant
Pin15 = 0v Fan Off, 0.05v Fan Spinning
Pin16 = 2.8v Fan Off, 10.02v Fan Spinning
Pin17 = 2.8v Fan Off, 10.72v Fan Spinning
Pin18 = 3.5v Fan Off, 11.4v Fan Spinning
Pin19 = 5.02v Constant
Pin20 = 5.02v Fan Off, 4.96v Fan Spinning
Pin21 = 0v Fan Off, 1.22v Fan Spinning
Pin22 = 0v
Pin23 = 3.5v Fluctuation Fan Off 14.6v Fan Spinning
Pin24 = 3.5v Fluctuation Fan Off 16.2v Fan Spinning
Pin25 = 4.53v Fluctuation Fan Off 14.6v Fan Spinning
Pin26 = 14.6v Fan Off, 14.3v Fan Spinning
Pin27 = 0v
Pin28 = 0v

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: Resistance between pins 17 and 18 should be about 3ohm and between 27 and 28 should be 20ohm, check if those values are true in your board please....

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: I don't buy "no resistance" between pins 17/18 and pins 27/28. Please do not use meter in beeping mode, it beeps even at 50 ohms. Read resistance off it and check again!

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message:
Thanks for the replies chaps. I've just had another go to be sure and it's definitely the same results as before. OL between those pins. I even changed the battery in the meter. So I understand the train of thought here, what will these results tell us?

Any idea what the ticking noise is that I can hear?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: :(:( OL is open line, the exact opposite of no resistance. Check all the resistors between those pins and check continuity between them.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message:
Sorry, my bad, lack of experience and lack of decent, unbroken sleep meant I ballsed up the terminology. 

Pins 27 and 28 have continuity to <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> are correct at 10ohm
Pins 17 and 18 have continuity to <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> (2.5ohm) and <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> (0.3ohm) 

Any clues on ticking noise?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: We mean resistance between the pins themselves, not to the resistors. Measure with one probe on pin 17, the other on pin 18, in resistance mode, and te same again for 27/28. This will tell us if there is a break in the current sensing circuit. if the machine an't sense how much current the battery or the charger is using it will turn it off, which is why you get a flickering light. Noise no idea, probably something switching on and off. Fix current sensing first.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message:
Tested again just now. No reading between Pins 17 and 18 or 27 and 28. So a break in the current sensing circuit then?

Again, apologies for the balls up and appreciate the patience.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: Yes. Find the broken link in the line.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message:
[QUOTE="jason_microsoldering, post: 16087"]:(:( OL is open line, the exact opposite of no resistance. Check all the resistors between those pins and check continuity between them.[/QUOTE]

Ok, so I retested the continuity. Same results.

Pin 27 has continuity to <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7022</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> which tests correctly @ 10ohm
Pin 28 has continuity to <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7021</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> which tests correctly @ 10ohm


Pin 17 has continuity to <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> which tests @ 0.3ohm, schematic says 0...?
Pin 18 has continuity to <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> which tests @ 2.5ohm, schematic says 2.2...


I'm a little lost of where to check next. I can't understand why, if the components are testing fine and continuity is fine why I'm not getting a reading between pins 17+18 and pins 27+28. Is the only explanation that the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> from the donor board is also bad or is there something else to check?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: [url]https://youtu.be/hpbzO2UjQQA[/url]

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: Have always been testing from the pins. Just checked at higher zoom and no line breaks. Continuity confirms this also, tested between pins and pads and every combination.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message:
I don't know how many other ways there are to tell you the same thing. Either you are using your multimeter incorrectly or you're looking at the wrong thing on the board.

Look at the schematic and find the two current sensing circuits, CSI and CSO. [B]Trace them out and back into the ISL with your finger[/B]. Measure the three [B]resistors[/B] for the correct resistance. Then measure that there is [B]no resistance[/B] between [B]each [/B]resistor along that path that you traced with your finger. Do the same for [B]both [/B]circuits.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message:
Although very much a beginner, I have used a multi meter many times before. I'm confident that I'm using the meter right and looking at the right thing on the board. I am definitely pushing the limits of my electronic knowledge though. Hence coming here.

So I have traced out with my finger and checked the board view for the traces. The resistors check out fine. Something that I missed before, in tracing out and testing, I did find that there is an OL between Pin 4 of <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> and Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>. On my donor boards these test as connected. Presume I can just run a wire to fix this? Is this likely to be the issue?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: Yes, fix the trace.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message: Cheers, will do in the morning.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Pulsing charger light
threads.message:
FIXED! Thanks to everyone that helped. Especially you, Jason. Much appreciated! That final post lead me right to the cause. I have learnt loads from this. Importantly, I have proved to myself that my soldering and hot air skills are up to the job.

I still don't get any reading from testing between those pins on the ISL, not that it matters now but still a mystery that I'd like to solve. Perhaps my multi meter is a bit crap? Works for everything else though.... Will see if I can borrow a more expensive one to test that theory before shelling out on a more expensive one.

Just need to tidy up the wire and all the other bits and pieces I have touched and then need to decide what ultrasonic to buy over here in the UK. Any suggestions?

[url]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZkdU5QsGlSg[/url]
